title: Do you like Nook or Kindle better? - Quora

response.answer_text: Wow, what a broad question! Maybe I’ve been watching too much anime, but the way it’s phrased makes me imagine Nook and Kindle as a pair of blushing Japanese schoolgirls competing furiously for the affection of senpai. When you get right down to it, Kindle and Nook are very similar formats with very similar capacities. They’re both built on fairly early-generation ebook technologies—the Kindle on Mobi, which Amazon bought, and Nook on the ePub format used by eReader and Fictionwise, which B&N bought. They’re basically just bare-bones text with fancy headers and emphasis, and the ability to insert pictures here and there. You can even crack the DRM on both of them with equal ease, thanks to a certain plug-in for Calibre. (Not that I do that, because that would be illegal, but it’s nice to know I could if I wanted to.) There’s not a whole lot to prefer or not on the basis of the format itself. But overall, I prefer Kindle, for several reasons. First of all, look at the relative performance of the companies behind them. Amazon is an e-commerce powerhouse which has grown year over year, regardless of whether it was able to turn a profit or not. While prognosticating the future of powerhouses is always risky—how many personal computers has IBM made lately?—it doesn’t seem likely that Amazon is in danger of going bankrupt any time soon. Barnes & Noble, on the other hand, has been hanging on by its fingernails for the last few years, and that’s largely because of the Nook division dragging the rest of it down like an anchor. It’s already started trimming the fat by backing out of the UK market altogether and outsourcing support duties to India. How much longer before the Nook fizzles out altogether, leaving customers unable to access the libraries they’ve paid good money for? One consequence of this is there are a lot more devices that can read Kindle ebooks, including every e-ink reader Amazon’s come out with for the last ten years, the Fire, and the applications for pretty much every OS platform. Nook has apps for multiple platforms, too, but not as well-supported, and it has a lot fewer devices. There’s also the fact that Kindle ebooks have that Whispersync thing that lets them sync up with Audible audiobooks, which Amazon also owns. Not exactly one of the major reasons I prefer Amazon, but certainly a cherry on top of the sundae. Amazon has a lot better customer-service track record, too. So, all things considered, I’ll buy my ebooks from there and give Barnes & Noble’s Nook a miss.

Definitely Nook, if we’re talking about pure e-readers. (Disclaimer: I researched this like 4 years ago, so I’m not sure how much it has changed since then. Also, I don’t have a Kindle.) (Disclaimer 2: I’m not affiliated with either Amazon or B&N. This is admittedly rather biased, but it’s not advertising.) For me, it’s kind of the same issue as iOS vs Android. Kindle is much more restrictive in every aspect, while Nook gives you a lot more freedom. Everything has to go through Amazon on Kindle, and the software is quite restricted. Sideloading is when you move ebooks from your computer to your device, rather than buying them from Amazon/Barnes and Noble. Project Gutenberg is a great resource with lots of public domain books. It looks like Kindle now supports sideloading, but they encourage you to buy from Amazon instead. Additionally, Kindle doesn’t support .epub, my favorite ebook format. Nook supports many more formats, and you can just drag and drop (like any other device). This kind of issue comes up a lot: if you want to rely on Amazon for everything, Kindle is just fine. But if you want a bit more control, you’ll want a Nook. Another big issue for me is software. Kindle is really restricted, while Nook is open. Nooks actually run a skinned version of Android (yes, even the e-readers). On the Nook Glowlight Plus, you can simply run a script to get full Android functionality. From there, you can install almost any apps you want (as .apk files). The old Nook Simple Touch attracted a strong developer community. They got the Google Play Store, “fastmode” (to optimize games for the e-reader screen), and even audio over USB working. One my new Nook, I just installed Moon Reader and Dropbox, then set it up to sync reading positions with my phone. It’s been really nice to just read a few pages anywhere. You can easily use your Nook as a Nook. Barnes and Noble has an online ebook store as well. But I like playing around with things, and the Nook is what really got me started. None of this would ever be possible on the Kindle. They don’t even let you change the screensaver! (It’s drag and drop for the Nook.) So, again, it ultimately comes down to personal preference. If you plan on letting Amazon handle everything, you’d be fine with the Kindle. But if you want more control of your device, you should go with Nook.

For a long time for me, it was a a bit of a toss-up. Kindle has access to more books, but I prefer the Nook hardware. I’d read a book on either. It usually came down to the price of the book or which one I was already reading a series on. However, recently Nook upgraded their hardware to the Nook Glowlight 3. Now I find reading on the Nook to be superior. Don’t get me wrong, the screen on my Paperwhite is excellent. However, I find myself reading much longer on the Nook when I have Night Node turned on than I do on my Paperwhite with just the white light. Night Mode is much easier on my eyes. The Nook Glowlight 3 also has a physical Home button and page turn buttons. None of the current line of Kindles has a physical home button. Only the top-of-the-line Oasis has page turn buttons. The Nook also supports more formats. With my Nook, I can also go to a Barnes & Noble store, get a cup of coffee or tea, and then spend up to an hour reading a book I don’t own while relaxing. It is a great way to decide whether or not I want to buy the book. It’s a wonderful perk. In terms of apps, it is Nook hands down. In the Kindle app you can no longer truly archive a book. All you can do is remove the contents of the book from your device (phone or tablet). The cover stays on the “My Library” page. There is no getting rid of it, unless you complete delete it - which means if you want to read it again, you have to buy it again. Good luck scrolling through every Kindle book you have ever owned to find something you’ve not read. The Nook app allows you to completely get rid of any trace of the book from your device. You don’t have to keep scrolling past the cover of a book you’ve long since read to get to one you haven’t or click down a couple of levels because you don’t remember if you took a break from a series at book 5 or at book 6. As I don’t read much on my phone or tablet, this bothers me far more than it probably should. Having used both a Kindle Paperwhite and the Nook, for me it is now the Nook without a doubt.

I love my Kindle. I have to confess that I have no practical knowledge of the Nook. The books are cheap. I like the interface. I like the highlighting and notes and multiple shelves. I like Kindle Unlimited. I prefer to get everything from one supplier so as not to end up getting duplicates of my books. But more seriously I used to get ebooks from Fictionwise. They were taken over by B & N and immediately I started having problems. They sold me books they shouldn’t have done because of territorial restrictions, and wouldn’t refund my money. Eventually I had obviously complained too much and their customer services stopped even acknowledging my emails. Ever since then I have not trusted them. Now there is a lot of evidence that the company is in trouble and I have no confidence in its continued existence. Amazon is going nowhere but up, and I have always found their customer service to be excellent.

I compared them both (B&W eInk versions) some years ago. After careful consideration, as I was deciding my SO purchased a Kindle Keyboard (old style). I played with it & liked it, so, I put in a pre-order for the newer Keyboard. I haven’t looked back since. Today? I have 2 Keyboards & 2 Fire HD 8.9s & a Fire HD 7. … And, yes, I actually use them all. PS. The advantage of my Keyboard eInk unit is that it has that built-in Cell access! So, if I am away from a free WiFi, I can still buy a book. Especially useful when away from home for a few days. … ADDED: The eInk Keyboard in bright sunlight & the Fire in the evening is a perfect pairing!

It really depends, if you are looking from a purely reading experience - Nook Glowlight 3 is the latest model from Barnes & Noble and it rocks! It has an amazing display which is easy for your eyes and just works well. I think B&N have gone back to the roots after not so successful release of Nook Glowlight Plus. Overall, I thin you need to make a choice on the ecosystem first, as that would greatly limit or should I say predetermine your buying options. If you want to read more about ebook readers, there a great online guide that would come hand for you I think - Kindle vs Nook comparison

I haven’t used a Nook much, although years ago we bought one for my grandmother. That was a reader, not a NookColor tablet, to be specific; my son had one of those. I found the Kindle e-reader (not the Fire) much easier to use. Although for the actual reading, both were on a par I think. I love the e-ink screen for reading. Amazon also had (or seemed to have, it might have changed) a larger selection of books. The Kindle was lighter, and easier to hold. So for me I much prefer a Kindle.

I have both and like both, but Amazon seems to have a larger selection of books. My Kindle is newer so it is also faster, but I imagine Nooks are faster now also. As an author, I find it much easier to publish with Amazon. However, Barnes and Noble is streamlining their process somewhat, so it may get easier.

They all use the same chips (or nearly the same chips) E-ink development is pretty specialized and the chip that drives the screen, the boards and the processors are almost all the same. What it comes down to is where you like to buy your books from. If you need to the don’t-think seamless delivery of Amazon, then buy a kindle. If you are a little bit more comfortable poking around with Adobe Digital Editions, use the Kobo or Nook readers. A little bit of time, thought and poking around in the MobileRead forums will save you a lot of time. I’m using a older Kobo with Adobe Digital Editions for library book management and Calibre for my personal collection.
